feed.title: Re: Safer sighashes and more granular SIGHASH_NOINPUT

entry.title: Re: Safer sighashes and more granular SIGHASH_NOINPUT
entry.summary:
Johnson Lau discusses the intricacies of generating signatures for transactions, highlighting four distinct levels of knowledge a signer might possess regarding the input they are using. These range from comprehensive knowledge about every input in the transaction to very limited information. The most detailed level of understanding is when the signer knows everything about every input involved in the transaction. A more confined level of knowledge pertains to knowing all details about only the input being signed, without insights into other inputs. Further narrowed down is the scenario where the signer is aware of the exact scriptPubKey they aim to satisfy but lacks knowledge of the txid. The most restricted level of knowledge, termed as SCRIPTMASK, involves not knowing the txid, the scriptPubKey, other taproot branches, or even masked terms within the script. However, the signer is aware of the script's structure and the terms that are not masked.
The discussion points out that masking information when signing is only meaningful at the SCRIPTMASK level since the txid and scriptPubKey already commit to the full scriptcode, making additional signatures redundant. Lau speculates on the practical utility of the SCRIPTPUBKEY option, suggesting it might be less useful as signers would either know the txid or need to mask certain elements.
In the context of taproot, the scriptPubKey is described as a point derived from a formula involving the base point Q, a hash function H(Q,S) multiplied by G, and S representing a merkle root of potentially multiple scripts. This setup allows for spending through various methods including signature verification, path(S,script), script, and witness(script). Furthermore, the SCRIPTMASK approach facilitates preparing a signature for a specific script in advance, even before finalizing other scripts or the base point Q, thereby offering flexibility in constructing transactions. This understanding underscores the potential advantages of taproot in enhancing privacy and efficiency in transaction scripting.
